caption: A very ordinary church from the outside, but the inside is spectacular.  Worth a visit to see the altar and the stained glass windows.

Fascinating and well worth a visit. We happened to be staying in the neighbourhood and wandered in, but it's a fascinating baroque-style building with essentially its own art gallery inside. Lots of beautiful stained glass and wall art, and a lovely, peaceful feeling, away from the busy chaos of the city outside.
Beautiful church. Try and visit while no masses are being held so you can walk up to the altar and look up into the rafters.

A little journey through time for this place filled with varied works, but with a favorite for the chapel known as "the souls of purgatory", architect Victor Louis (that of the great theater of Bordeaux among others) This chapel is especially remarkable for the ample trompe l'oeil created by Paolo Antonio Brunetti(1723-1783). Enough to understand what his decoration was for the chapel of missing children in Haussman's work on the Île de la Cité.

A marvel! I really liked everything. The modest exterior then the interior...of breathtaking beauty and sobriety. Magnificent paintings, the chapel of the Souls of Purgatory, the beauty of the Choir... Magnificent! Easy access. I highly recommend ❤
An oasis of tranquility in a beautiful green area. Beautiful painted, historical paintings.

In 1624, Jean de Vitry donated land to Antoine Fayet, priest of Saint Paul, who built a chapel dedicated to Saint Marguerite of Antioch. From a branch church in 1634 it became a parish church in 1712.  During the French Revolution, the bodies of 300 people guillotined on the Bastille and Nation squares were buried in the cemetery of the same church and, according to legend, Louis XVII was buried in the latter after his death at the Temple prison. . But that's the legend...  The interior is elegantly sober and can be visited with complete humility.  To discover if you are in the neighborhood.

From the outside, the nondescript church is one of the last in Paris to have an adjoining cemetery. It was long believed that Louis XVII as a child, after his death in the Temple Prison, had been buried here. We have since known that this is false. You should not miss visiting it, because this church is the only one to have a "Chapel of the Souls of Purgatory" listed as a Historic Monument in 1960. It is all decorated in "Trompe l'Oeil" in a neo-classical Greek style. .. This is absolutely remarkable and astonishing! A visit worth the detour!

A stone's throw from my home, I had never visited this place of worship. I stayed there for a long time listening to the music playing there, with beautiful acoustics. The place is beautiful, peaceful, with pretty paintings. I find the proportions of the church superb, the place is magical in the sense that we want to give it.

A magnificent church which has just celebrated its 400 years of existence in a historic district of Paris, from the artisans of the Faubourg Saint Antoine to the Place de la Bastille. The interior is beautiful and very well maintained. In addition, the Town Hall has just put up several posters along the gates of the square which adjoins the Sainte Marguerite church which explain the different moments that it has gone through since its creation... it's great!
Super church which has the particularity of having a chapel dedicated to the very rare souls of purgatory Quality welcome and information
One of the most beautiful churches in Paris. Great team, Father Dufour, priest and Clément François, organist, especially.
I found in this church the charm of village churches. The priests are listening. The stained glass windows are magnificent. A must see

Well-preserved architectural ensemble.    It would be nice if the Paris City Hall wanted to review its historical information panel and mention that the heart of the child who died at the Temple is indeed that of Louis 17. ADN, 2000. Who according to oral tradition was buried in a pit commune of the cemetery of Ste Marguerite.   His bones were never found. His heart yes, preserved by a forensic doctor, and now in St Denis.  Even if you are not a royalist, the fate of the 10-year-old child, voluntarily forgotten to death in a damp jail, sick without care, is painful.   A mysterious memory hangs over the place.
Very beautiful church

Pretty classical style church dating from the 17th century. Sober and neat decoration. At the back of the nave you can see a large overhanging stained glass window representing Saint Marguerite. There reigns calm and serenity.
the church is quite anonymous compared to a thousand other monuments in Paris but the mass celebrated is exciting and moving with an exceptional guiding voice
This church is magnificent, I wanted to see the tomb of Louis 17 but I did not dare to ask, I will surely come back, there are magnificent paintings inside. Nice little church.

I could write the same thing as “Françoise” who has just given her opinion here! This church, a little hidden in the small streets and near Nordling Square, doesn't look much from the outside...and it would be barely there if we didn't go in... I immediately found it quite mysterious...the lighting is all chiaroscuro, a bit like a Rembrandt painting.... Of course this famous chapel of the souls of Purgatory is quite fascinating, unfortunately closed, we can only contemplate it through the bars of the gate... The cemetery, supposed to contain poor little Louis XVII, does indeed contain the remains of 73 people guillotined in Place de la Bastille....when human cruelty gives free rein... Go and seek appeasement in this peaceful chiaroscuro in the face of centuries-old human violence....
Little-known yet remarkable church
Magnificent church! The very square of the church behind is lovely and we discover the architecture and the pretty bell tower. It looks like a pretty village church. Lots of charm.
Beautiful 17th-19th century church in the 11th arrondissement. Lots of works of art with a jewel which is the chapel of the souls of purgatory.

Wonderful little church rich in history and all high up in the nave, small AND large organs, stained glass windows ++ very motivated Christian community in the St Bernard district, songs, texts, adorable children...in short, our authentic old Paris...my God. ..obvious spiritual warmth...how good it feels + in these times of upheaval - planetary change..!
Very beautiful 17th century church. Unique painting by Dorigny. Collected atmosphere. Sober and beautiful architecture.
It is a beautiful and very large church which exudes peace and tranquility in this part of Paris invaded by the numerous shops and squares which surround it.
It is always a joy to replace the organist François Clément and to accompany the beautiful liturgy of the masses with Father Bertrand Dufour and his team.  Carolyn SHUSTER FOURNIER
Beautiful church to visit! a beautiful bas relief in the choir and an extraordinary trompe l'oeil in the chapel of the souls of purgatory.
disappointed by the accompaniments and the long wait (a Sunday lunch). the meats are very good but we didn't realize that the prime rib had to be ordered 48 hours in advance
Very old church, with a spiritual and comforting internal atmosphere.
Very beautiful church with many stained glass windows dedicated to the soldier of the Second World War, an atypical church with a square plate covered with slates
restored church with traces of its historical past the body of young Louis xvii would have been buried along its walls
This church is little known, apart from the chapel of the angels of purgatory, but take the trouble to search on Google which will give you information and come and visit it.
The Chapel of Souls in Purgatory is a marvel unknown to Parisians.
It’s a little-known church in the 11th arrondissement that I discovered with pleasure.
To visit soon it looks pretty
It is a place of serenity and beauty in Paris, in a craft district with a nostalgic past
Each church has its own atmosphere and St Marguerite has the charm of a neighborhood church.
Magnificent painting to see. Urgent need for restoration regarding the church.
